On July 7, the U.S. started to reopen the border to Mexican livestock, but shortly thereafter, on July 9, the suspension was [reimposed](https://www.beefmagazine.com/market-news/cattle-trade-with-mexico-if-you-blinked-you-missed-it) after another NWS case was detected.

As of November 4, 2025, there is still [no time frame for reopening the border](https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-not-ready-lift-mexican-cattle-ban-over-screwworm-agriculture-secretary-2025-11-04/), but USDA Secretary Brooke Rollins is reportedly "pleased with with Mexico's efforts to contain the pest," stating that, "every day that goes by we get a little bit closer."

**USDA Opens Mexican Facility for Controlling Spread of Flesh-Eating New World Screwworm**
The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced the opening of a new sterile fly dispersal facility in Tampico, Mexico, on November 13, 2025, as part of a coordinated effort to prevent the spread of New World screwworm (NWS) flies into the United States. NWS flies are parasitic insects that lay eggs in wounds or bodily orifices of warm-blooded animals; upon hatching, the larvae burrow into the tissue and feed on living flesh, causing severe tissue damage and often leading to the death of the host animal. A single female NWS fly can lay up to 3,000 eggs in her lifetime, making infestations highly destructive to livestock. The facility will release sterile male flies to disrupt reproduction and reduce the population of harmful NWS flies, thereby protecting U.S. agricultural interests. The announcement was made in a USDA statement released on November 14, 2025, by The Epoch Times.

**USDA confirms new sterile fly facility in Northern Mexico**
The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced on November 13, 2025, the opening of a sterile fly dispersal facility in Tampico, Mexico, as part of its efforts to prevent the spread of New World screwworm (NWS) into the United States. The Tampico facility enables aerial dispersal of sterile flies across northeastern Mexico, including Nuevo León, enhancing the USDA’s ability to respond quickly to outbreaks. US Secretary of Agriculture Brooke L. Rollins stated the facility is a critical tool in the fight against screwworm, emphasizing its role in pushing the pest southward. The USDA is implementing a five-pronged strategy with Mexico, including aerial dispersal and ground release chambers. Aerial operations are preferred for large-scale, hard-to-reach areas, while ground chambers allow rapid deployment outside facility range. The USDA currently releases 100 million sterile flies per week in Mexico, but aerial dispersal had previously been limited to southern Mexico. Although new NWS cases have been confirmed in southern Mexico, there has been no significant northward spread; the two most northern detections were in Nuevo León on September 20 and October 5, 2025, in cattle from Chiapas, both inactive with no further detections. The USDA is transitioning from ground release chambers to aerial dispersal in Nuevo León. Sterile flies are produced at the COPEG facility in Panama, and the USDA is investing $21 million to help Mexico renovate a fruit fly facility in Metapa, which will double NWS production capacity once completed—expected to begin operations by summer 2026. Additionally, the USDA plans a $750 million investment to build the first domestic sterile NWS fly production facility at Moore Air Base in Edinburg, Texas, projected to be operational by early 2026. APHIS is also expediting construction of a sterile fly facility in Southern Texas with a target capacity of 300 million sterile flies per week.

**TCFA Participates in USDA-Led Agribusiness Trade Mission to Mexico**
The U.S. Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) Foreign Agricultural Service led an agribusiness trade mission to Mexico City, Mexico, from November 10–14, 2025, with over 150 U.S. exporters, agriculture trade organizations, and USDA officials participating. The mission aimed to strengthen export opportunities for American farmers, ranchers, and agribusinesses, supporting rural prosperity and global competitiveness. Mexico remains a key trade partner, especially for U.S. cattle imports and beef exports. TCFA representatives—Past Chairman Robby Kirkland, Board Member Alvaro Bustillos, and President & CEO Ben Weinheimer—attended meetings, events, and site visits. USDA Secretary Brooke Rollins emphasized that U.S. exports to Mexico have grown by 57% since the USMCA took effect in 2020, totaling over $120 billion in additional trade. She highlighted ongoing cooperation with Mexico to combat the New World Screwworm (NWS), stating that the U.S. has been more aggressive than any previous administration in addressing the issue. Rollins also noted progress toward reopening U.S. ports, though no timeline was announced, and affirmed the need for thorough verification and coordination with top officials, including President Trump. Kirkland reported that meetings with Mexico’s Secretary of Agriculture Dr. Julio A. Berdegué Sacristán, SENASICA (the country’s animal health agency), CNOG (National Confederation of Livestock Organizations), UGRCH (Chihuahua Cattlemen’s Association), and the American Chamber of Commerce of Mexico revealed Mexico’s advanced, technology-driven NWS control efforts, including a real-time monitoring center with over 1,000 employees nationwide. Rollins met with Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum, and in a Reuters interview, she stated that while ports are not yet open, progress is being made daily and every tool is being deployed to ensure safety.

Potential factors include Argentine beef import volumes, possible tariff relaxation on Brazilian beef, and the prospect of reopening the U.S.-Mexico border to Mexican cattle. President Trump’s rhetoric on high beef prices may also be influencing market psychology. However, the primary driver appears to be managed money avoiding uncertainty, with a likely 'RESET' in positioning. Cash markets remained relatively stable: $230 per hundredweight in the North and $232 in the South, though $3–$4 lower than the previous week. December live cattle ended at $221, down from a peak of $248 in mid-October, while cash prices only reached $240–$241. Technical analysis shows large downside gaps on daily charts, with no breach of the prior week’s gap, indicating a weak market structure. Few traders are willing to go long until clarity returns. **President Trump calls for DOJ investigation into meatpacking plants**
President Donald Trump called for an immediate Department of Justice (DOJ) investigation into meatpacking companies, alleging they are driving up beef prices through 'illicit collusion, price fixing, and price manipulation' on Truth Social. He cited record-high beef prices nationwide expected to persist into 2026 and the lowest U.S. cattle herd inventory since 1951. In response, Julie Anna Potts, president and CEO of the Meat Institute, stated that beef packers have been operating at a loss due to record-high cattle prices and tight supply, despite elevated consumer prices. She emphasized that the beef industry is heavily regulated, transactions are transparent, and USDA data confirms ongoing losses projected through 2026. The Meat Institute welcomed a fact-based discussion on beef affordability. R-CALF USA, represented by CEO Bill Bullard, supported the DOJ investigation, arguing there is a longstanding disconnect between cattle and beef prices, which indicates market failure, and called for a competitive market to ensure fair prices for producers and consumers. The National Cattlemen’s Beef Association (NCBA) cautioned in October that market manipulation efforts risk harming American cattlemen without significantly lowering consumer prices. A new USDA cattle plan was introduced by Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins in response to Trump’s earlier comments about increased beef imports from Argentina.

**Exclusive-US Not Ready to Lift Mexican Cattle Ban Over Screwworm, Agriculture Secretary Rollins Says**
U.S. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins stated on November 4, 2025, during an exclusive interview in Mexico City, that the United States is not yet ready to lift the ban on Mexican cattle imports due to an ongoing outbreak of the flesh-eating New World screwworm parasite. Although President Donald Trump is focused on reopening the border—closed since May—Rollins emphasized that the U.S. must ensure complete confidence in containment efforts before lifting restrictions. She praised Mexico’s improved cooperation, calling it 'the most collaborative effort, perhaps in our lifetime, between the two different departments of agriculture,' and noted that 11 screwworm cases in Mexican border states have been contained. Rollins highlighted that the parasite, which lays eggs in wounds and whose larvae consume living tissue, has not yet crossed into the U.S., but poses a significant threat, with potential damages to Texas' economy estimated at $1.8 billion. She acknowledged that illegal cattle trafficking, involving forged documents and stolen livestock from Central America, remains a major concern, though Mexico has strengthened checkpoints and protections. Despite about 250,000 cattle waiting to enter the U.S. and rising beef prices, Rollins insisted that safety is paramount, stating, 'We can never compromise the safety of the herd for the cost,' and that premature reopening could lead to far greater long-term economic damage.

Mexico has reported more than 500 active cases in cattle across southern states, and the block on cattle imports has caused the government and ranchers to seek lifting the ban, which could cost the ranching federation up to $400 million if it remains in place through the year. U.S. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins said Washington will take "decisive measures to protect our borders, even in the absence of cooperation" and that imports of Mexican cattle, bison and horses will remain suspended. "We will not rely on Mexico to defend our industry, our food supply or our way of life," she added. Beef prices in the United States reached a record high of $6.12 per pound for ground beef in June 2025, up from $5.98 in May and $5.47 in June 2024, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. Despite the end of peak grilling season, ground beef prices remain historically elevated due to tight cattle supplies and strong demand. Danyelle Chinn, research analyst at the University of Missouri Rural and Farm Finance Policy Analysis Center (RaFF), noted that while high prices signal positive conditions for cattle producers, consumers are bearing the financial impact. The root causes include multiple years of drought, which reduced forage and hay availability, forcing producers to cull herds and reduce heifer retention. As a result, current beef cow numbers are the lowest since 1961. Additionally, the USDA closed the border to cattle imports from Mexico due to the northward spread of New World screwworms, further reducing supply. Feedlots in the southern U.S. rely on Mexican cattle, so the import ban has tightened the domestic supply. High input costs have also limited herd expansion. Despite rising prices, demand remains strong—driven by summer grilling and high-protein consumer trends—creating a 'perfect storm' of limited supply and robust demand. Tucker from MU Extension stated that rebuilding the herd will take years, meaning short-term prices may rise further. A potential drop in prices could only occur with increased supply or reduced demand, such as from an economic downturn causing consumers to switch to cheaper proteins. For now, consumers face continued high costs at the meat counter.

**Santa Teresa Cattle Crossing to Remain Closed Due to New World Screw-worm Parasite Detection**
The Santa Teresa cattle crossing, the largest in the US-Mexico border, will not reopen on July 21 as planned due to the detection of an additional case of the New World Screw-worm parasite in Mexico. The crossing has been closed since May 11 after the US Secretary of Agriculture, Brooke Rollins, announced the immediate suspension of live cattle, horse, and bison imports from the US following the detection of the parasite in southern Mexico. The USDA had published a plan in July to reopen the crossing in stages, but new cases were detected in northern Mexico, forcing the closure of all crossings. The Secretary of Agriculture for the New Mexico Department of Agriculture, Jeff Witte, stated that the impact of the continued closure on New Mexico's agriculture is small but has significant implications for the national beef industry. 'The majority of cattle that enter through Santa Teresa end up in feedlots or pastures in other states, destined for places like Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas, and Nebraska,' Witte said. 'At some point, there were trucks from 17 different states picking up cattle.' The movement of the parasite, previously eradicated from the US for decades, has disrupted international cattle trade through New Mexico, Arizona, and Texas. The USDA has announced the construction of a $8.5 million facility to breed sterilized flies to prevent further reproduction in the wild, located in the Moore Air Base in Mission, Texas, and $21 million to produce more sterile flies in a facility in Metapa, Mexico. The USDA also stated that it will increase monitoring and data exchange with Mexican officials along the border. However, Mexican agricultural agents detected a new case in Veracruz, 370 miles from the border, on July 7, forcing the USDA to cancel the reopening plan. 'The US has promised to be vigilant -- and after detecting this new case of NWS, we are pausing the planned reopening of the port to quarantine more and attack this deadly plague in Mexico,' Rollins said in a written statement on July 9. 'We must see additional progress in combating NWS in Veracruz and other nearby Mexican states to reopen cattle ports along the southern border.' Daniel Manzanares, the director of the Santa Teresa international crossing, stated that the USDA has not said when the reopening will occur. The crossing is privately owned by the Cooperativa Unión Ganadera Regional de Chihuahua, which often moves cattle from northern Mexico to feedlots in the US. The plague has not been detected in the northern part of Mexico, but cattle still cannot cross. In previous years, approximately 270,000 animals would have crossed the border by now, said Manzanares. This year, with the closures, only a third, or 74,000, have made it across, requiring the layoffs of half of the workers hired to transport cattle. 'It has severely impacted all types of industry here below, from truckers to buyers, cattle runners, we've laid off employees who won't return,' said Manzanares. 'It's simply breaking a lot of people'.
